description: From Anglo-Norman vesterie, from Old French vestiaire (“room for vestments, dressing room”), from Latin vestiarium (“wardrobe”). Doublet of vestiary.

entries.meaning: A room in a church where the clergy put on their vestments and where these are stored; also used for meetings and classes; a sacristy.
examples: The choirboys change into their cassocks in the vestry.

entries.meaning: A committee of parishioners elected to administer the temporal affairs of a parish.
examples: The vestry meets on the first Tuesday of every month.

entries.meaning: An assembly of persons who manage parochial affairs; so called because usually held in a vestry.
